back: Condition where limited resources cannot satisfy unlimited wants, forcing choices about what to produce, how, and for whom
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students confuse scarcity (permanent, everywhere) with a temporary market shortage

back: The value of the next best alternative foregone when a choice is made
CLEP Trap: Trap: Often misinterpreted as the sum of all alternatives given up instead of just the single highest-valued one

back: Decision-making by comparing the additional (marginal) benefit of one more unit to the additional (marginal) cost
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students answer based on total or average values rather than marginal values

back: Graph showing maximum combinations of two goods that can be produced with given resources and technology
CLEP Trap: Trap: Points inside PPC are not 'unattainable'; they are inefficient or represent unemployment

back: Shown as an outward shift of the entire PPC due to more resources, better technology, or improved institutions
CLEP Trap: Trap: Moving along an existing PPC is not growth; it is reallocation of resources

back: Ability of a producer to make more of a good with the same inputs than another producer
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students use absolute advantage to decide specialization; comparative advantage is what matters for trade

back: Ability to produce a good at a lower opportunity cost than another producer
CLEP Trap: Trap: Many pick the producer who can make more units instead of the one with the lower opportunity cost

back: Rate at which goods are exchanged between countries; beneficial if between each country’s opportunity cost for that good
CLEP Trap: Trap: Accepting trading ratios outside the opportunity cost range that benefit only one country

back: As price decreases, quantity demanded increases, ceteris paribus, and vice versa
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing a 'change in demand' (shift) with a 'change in quantity demanded' (movement along the curve)

back: As price increases, quantity supplied increases, ceteris paribus, and vice versa
CLEP Trap: Trap: Thinking 'an increase in supply' refers to movement up the curve caused by higher price rather than an actual rightward shift

back: Income, tastes, prices of related goods, expectations, and number of buyers shift the entire demand curve
CLEP Trap: Trap: Treating a price change of the good itself as a demand shifter instead of a movement along the curve

back: Input prices, technology, taxes and subsidies, expectations, and number of sellers shift the supply curve
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students misinterpret a movement along supply from a price change as a shift in supply

back: Goods that can replace each other; when the price of one rises, demand for the other rises
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing substitutes with complements, reversing the direction of demand shifts

back: Goods consumed together; when the price of one rises, demand for the other falls
CLEP Trap: Trap: Treating complements as substitutes so they predict the opposite demand change

back: Price and quantity at which quantity demanded equals quantity supplied; no inherent tendency for change
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students assume equilibrium is 'fair' or 'socially optimal' rather than simply the intersection of S and D

back: Quantity demanded exceeds quantity supplied at a price below equilibrium
CLEP Trap: Trap: Calling any high price a shortage instead of checking Qd versus Qs at that price

back: Quantity supplied exceeds quantity demanded at a price above equilibrium
CLEP Trap: Trap: Labeling surpluses as shortages because the price is 'too low' conceptually, instead of referencing Qd and Qs

back: Legal maximum price; if set below equilibrium, it is binding and creates a shortage
CLEP Trap: Trap: Mixing up which policy (ceiling or floor) creates shortages versus surpluses

back: Legal minimum price; if set above equilibrium, it is binding and creates a surplus
CLEP Trap: Trap: Thinking minimum wage (a price floor) causes a shortage of labor rather than a surplus (unemployment) if binding

back: Area between the demand curve and the price line up to the quantity traded; measures buyer benefit above price paid
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students compute total revenue instead of the triangular surplus area or misidentify the region on the graph

back: Area between the price line and the supply curve up to the quantity traded; measures seller benefit above minimum acceptable price
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing producer surplus with profit or using the wrong area under demand instead of above supply

back: Sum of consumer and producer surplus; maximized at competitive equilibrium
CLEP Trap: Trap: Assuming monopolies or price controls can increase total surplus compared to competition

back: Loss of total surplus that occurs when quantity traded is less than the efficient competitive equilibrium (or more, in some distortions)
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students shade the tax rectangle or entire area between supply and demand instead of only the small triangle representing lost trades

back: Measure of responsiveness of quantity demanded to a change in price: Ed = (% change in quantity demanded) / (% change in price)
CLEP Trap: Trap: Reversing the fraction (price over quantity) or forgetting to use percentage changes

back: Elastic: absolute value of Ed greater than 1; inelastic: absolute value of Ed less than 1; unit elastic: absolute value of Ed equals 1
CLEP Trap: Trap: Treating 'steeper' visually as always more inelastic without considering actual percent changes

back: TR = price * quantity; when demand is elastic, price and total revenue move in opposite directions; when inelastic, they move in the same direction
CLEP Trap: Trap: Memorizing rules but then applying them backward under exam pressure

back: Measures responsiveness of demand to changes in income; positive for normal goods, negative for inferior goods
CLEP Trap: Trap: Calling a good 'normal' or 'inferior' based on price changes instead of income changes

back: Measures responsiveness of demand for one good to price changes of another; positive for substitutes, negative for complements
CLEP Trap: Trap: Misreading the sign, so they label complements as substitutes or vice versa

back: Normal: demand increases when income rises; inferior: demand decreases when income rises
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing inferior goods with low-quality goods; 'inferior' is about income response, not quality

back: A theoretical inferior good for which demand increases when its price rises because of strong income effect
CLEP Trap: Trap: Over-applying this rare case to justify upward-sloping demand in normal questions

back: A measure of satisfaction or happiness from consuming goods and services
CLEP Trap: Trap: Treating utility as something objectively measurable in dollars instead of a theoretical concept

back: The additional satisfaction from consuming one more unit of a good or service
CLEP Trap: Trap: Using total utility instead of marginal utility in decision rules

back: As more units of a good are consumed, marginal utility eventually declines
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students think total utility must fall when marginal utility decreases; total utility can still rise as long as MU remains positive

back: Consumers maximize utility when marginal utility per dollar is equal across all goods and the budget is fully spent
CLEP Trap: Trap: Setting MU of X equal to MU of Y instead of MUx / Px equal to MUy / Py

back: A line showing all combinations of goods a consumer can afford given income and prices
CLEP Trap: Trap: Misinterpreting a pivot as an income change instead of a price change

back: Change in quantity demanded caused by a change in consumer purchasing power (real income) from a price change
CLEP Trap: Trap: Attributing all quantity changes to substitution effect when some are income effect

back: Change in quantity demanded caused by a good becoming relatively cheaper or more expensive compared to alternatives
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing substitution effect with a shift of the demand curve rather than movement along it

front: Short run vs long run in production
back: Short run: at least one input is fixed; long run: all inputs are variable
CLEP Trap: Trap: Defining short run and long run by calendar time instead of fixed versus variable inputs

back: Total output produced by a given amount of inputs
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing TP with average or marginal product on tables and graphs

back: Additional output produced by one more unit of a variable input, holding other inputs fixed
CLEP Trap: Trap: Using change in input divided by change in output instead of output change divided by input change

back: As more units of a variable input are added to fixed inputs, marginal product eventually decreases
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students think returns become negative immediately instead of first rising then diminishing

back: Cost that does not vary with output in the short run (for example, rent)
CLEP Trap: Trap: Treating labor costs as fixed when they are usually variable

back: Cost that varies with output (for example, wages, materials)
CLEP Trap: Trap: Including fixed costs like long-term lease payments as variable

back: Sum of fixed and variable costs: TC = FC + VC
CLEP Trap: Trap: Double-counting costs when moving from FC and VC to TC

back: Total cost divided by quantity of output: ATC = TC / Q
CLEP Trap: Trap: Forgetting that ATC includes both fixed and variable costs, not just variable

back: Variable cost divided by quantity of output: AVC = VC / Q
CLEP Trap: Trap: Using TC instead of VC in the numerator

back: Fixed cost divided by quantity of output: AFC = FC / Q
CLEP Trap: Trap: Expecting AFC to be U-shaped; it continuously declines as output rises

back: Change in total cost resulting from producing one more unit: MC = change in TC / change in Q
CLEP Trap: Trap: Using average cost formulas when a question specifically asks for marginal cost

back: MC intersects both ATC and AVC at their minimum points
CLEP Trap: Trap: Mislabeling curves so they conclude MC crosses ATC at the wrong quantity

back: A firm should shut down in the short run if price is less than AVC; if price is at least AVC, it should produce even if price is below ATC
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing shutdown point (P < AVC) with break-even point (P = ATC)

back: Long-run average total cost decreases as output increases due to specialization and spreading fixed costs
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing economies of scale (LR concept) with diminishing marginal returns (SR concept)

back: Long-run average total cost increases as output increases due to coordination and management problems
CLEP Trap: Trap: Attributing diseconomies to rising marginal cost in the short run rather than to long-run scale issues

back: Many small firms, identical products, free entry and exit, and price-taking behavior
CLEP Trap: Trap: Thinking a competitive firm faces a downward-sloping demand curve; it faces a perfectly elastic (horizontal) demand at market price

back: Any firm maximizes profit by producing the quantity where marginal revenue equals marginal cost (MR = MC)
CLEP Trap: Trap: Using 'produce where ATC is minimized' or 'where profit is highest' without checking MR and MC equality

back: Profit = total revenue − total cost; total revenue = price * quantity
CLEP Trap: Trap: Using price minus ATC without multiplying by quantity when calculating total profit

back: If price > ATC, the firm earns economic profit; if ATC > price > AVC, the firm loses money but stays open; if price < AVC, the firm shuts down
CLEP Trap: Trap: Misapplying shutdown rule by focusing on ATC instead of AVC

back: Entry and exit drive economic profits to zero; firms produce where price equals minimum ATC and price equals MC
CLEP Trap: Trap: Thinking zero economic profit means firms are indifferent to staying in the industry; they still cover all opportunity costs

back: Occurs when price equals marginal cost (P = MC), meaning resources go to goods valued most highly by consumers
CLEP Trap: Trap: Believing any equilibrium is allocatively efficient even when P ≠ MC (such as in monopoly)

back: Occurs when production uses the lowest possible cost per unit, at the minimum of ATC
CLEP Trap: Trap: Assuming monopolies or monopolistic competition are productively efficient in the long run; only perfect competition is

back: Single seller, unique product, high barriers to entry, and price-making power
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing monopoly with monopolistic competition (which has many firms and product differentiation)

back: Monopolist faces the market demand curve; marginal revenue is below demand because to sell more, price must fall on all units
CLEP Trap: Trap: Drawing MR equal to demand as in perfect competition

back: Monopolist produces where MR = MC and charges the price on the demand curve at that quantity
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students mistakenly set price equal to MC or ATC to find monopoly quantity

back: Loss of total surplus because monopolist restricts output below competitive level and charges higher price
CLEP Trap: Trap: Shading the entire area between monopolist and competitive prices instead of just the lost trade triangle

back: Charging different prices to different consumers for the same product based on willingness to pay, not cost differences
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing legal forms (student discounts) with illegal discrimination; exam focuses on economic idea

back: Monopolist charges each customer their maximum willingness to pay, capturing all consumer surplus
CLEP Trap: Trap: Assuming perfect price discrimination increases deadweight loss; it actually eliminates DWL in the simple model

back: Many firms, differentiated products, relatively easy entry and exit
CLEP Trap: Trap: Calling it 'a monopoly' because each firm has some market power; it is structurally more like perfect competition long run

back: Firms earn zero economic profit; demand curve is tangent to ATC at MR = MC; there is excess capacity
CLEP Trap: Trap: Thinking they produce at minimum ATC; they operate with excess capacity instead

back: Few large firms, significant barriers to entry, possible collusion, and mutual interdependence
CLEP Trap: Trap: Treating oligopoly like perfect competition or monopoly without recognizing strategic interaction

back: Tool to analyze strategic interactions where each firm's outcome depends on its own choice and rivals’ choices
CLEP Trap: Trap: Picking outcomes that maximize joint profit without checking if each firm has incentive to deviate (Nash equilibrium condition)

back: Situation where no player can gain by unilaterally changing their strategy, given others’ strategies
CLEP Trap: Trap: Choosing the outcome with highest combined payoff instead of the one where neither player wants to deviate alone

back: A strategy that yields a higher payoff for a player regardless of the opponent’s action
CLEP Trap: Trap: Thinking every game has a dominant strategy; many do not

back: Model suggesting oligopoly firms face a demand curve that is more elastic for price increases than for price cuts, leading to sticky prices
CLEP Trap: Trap: Over-applying kinked demand model when an exam question is really about collusion or standard oligopoly

back: Group of firms acting together to maximize joint profits, often by restricting output and raising price
CLEP Trap: Trap: Assuming cartels are stable; in theory each member has an incentive to cheat

back: Explicit: direct monetary payments; implicit: opportunity costs of owner's resources used in business
CLEP Trap: Trap: Calculating economic profit using only explicit costs (accounting profit) and ignoring implicit costs

back: Accounting profit = total revenue − explicit costs; economic profit = total revenue − (explicit + implicit costs)
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing zero economic profit with zero accounting profit; zero economic profit usually implies positive accounting profit

back: Additional revenue a firm earns from employing one more unit of a factor: MRP = MP * MR
CLEP Trap: Trap: Forgetting that in a perfectly competitive output market MR equals price, so MRP equals MP times price

back: Additional cost of employing one more unit of a factor (often equal to wage in competitive labor markets)
CLEP Trap: Trap: Using average factor cost instead of marginal when applying hiring rule

back: Hire labor until MRP equals MFC (often wage); beyond that, additional workers reduce profit
CLEP Trap: Trap: Setting MRP equal to wage but then hiring even when MRP < wage in tables

back: Labor demand depends on demand for the output the labor helps produce; it is 'derived' from product market demand
CLEP Trap: Trap: Treating labor demand as independent of product price or productivity

back: Wage and employment determined where labor demand (MRP) equals labor supply
CLEP Trap: Trap: Thinking a single competitive firm can influence market wage by adjusting its own hiring

back: A labor market with a single or dominant buyer of labor that faces an upward-sloping labor supply and has MFC above wage
CLEP Trap: Trap: Treating monopsony like monopoly in the product market and drawing the wrong curves

back: Unions can push wages above competitive levels, possibly causing unemployment if binding
CLEP Trap: Trap: Assuming any wage increase from unions always raises employment

back: Situation where a firm’s production imposes external costs (like pollution) on others, causing overproduction relative to the socially optimal level
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students shift demand instead of supply when the externality is on the cost side

back: Situation where a consumer’s consumption provides benefits to others (like vaccines), causing underconsumption relative to the socially optimal level
CLEP Trap: Trap: Moving supply instead of demand; consumption externalities shift demand

back: Quantity where marginal social benefit equals marginal social cost
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing private equilibrium (where MPB = MPC) with social optimum (MSB = MSC)

back: Tax designed to internalize a negative externality by making firms face the full social cost, reducing output to the socially optimal level
CLEP Trap: Trap: Believing any tax is Pigouvian; it must be targeted to equal marginal external cost

back: Subsidy designed to internalize a positive externality by increasing private benefit to match social benefit
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing generic subsidies (like farm price supports) with externality-correcting subsidies

back: Good that is nonrival and nonexcludable, such as national defense or street lighting
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students define any government-provided good as a public good, even when it is rival and excludable

back: People can benefit from a public good without paying, leading markets to underprovide such goods
CLEP Trap: Trap: Applying free-rider problem to private goods rather than nonexcludable ones

back: Good that is rival but nonexcludable, like open-access fisheries or public grazing land
CLEP Trap: Trap: Confusing common resources with public goods; common resources can be depleted by overuse

back: Overuse and depletion of a common resource because individual users ignore the external cost they impose on others
CLEP Trap: Trap: Attributing the problem to high prices rather than lack of property rights or exclusion

back: Good that is nonrival but excludable, like a subscription streaming service with low marginal cost of an extra user
CLEP Trap: Trap: Students lump club goods with public goods or private goods without checking both criteria

back: Binding ceilings transfer surplus from producers to consumers but create deadweight loss from lost trades
CLEP Trap: Trap: Ignoring the deadweight loss and thinking ceilings always 'help consumers overall'

back: Binding floors transfer surplus from consumers to producers (in some cases) but create deadweight loss and often require government purchases
CLEP Trap: Trap: Overlooking government budget costs and DWL while focusing only on changed producer surplus

back: The side of the market that is more inelastic bears more of the economic burden of a tax
CLEP Trap: Trap: Assuming legal incidence (who remits tax) determines who actually bears the burden

back: Subsidies shift supply (or demand) and generally increase quantity traded, but also create deadweight loss and budget cost
CLEP Trap: Trap: Assuming subsidies always increase total surplus; they increase CS and PS but create DWL from overproduction

front: Short run vs long run in micro markets
back: Short run: some inputs fixed and number of firms fixed; long run: all inputs variable and firms can enter or exit
CLEP Trap: Trap: Ignoring entry and exit in long-run questions and treating the situation as static

back: Profits attract entry, shifting each firm’s demand left until only normal profit remains
CLEP Trap: Trap: Thinking entry shifts industry supply, not individual firm demand, in this model

front: Key difference: monopoly vs monopolistic competition
back: Monopoly has one firm and high barriers; monopolistic competition has many firms and free entry with differentiated products
CLEP Trap: Trap: Choosing 'monopoly' when a scenario clearly describes many firms and advertising/differentiation
